Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Evolution and Function of Complex Signaling in the Wolf Spider Genus Schizocosa
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals can use several sensory modalities to communicate and recent research highlights the prevalence of complex signaling in animal displays (e.g. the combination of more than one signal often across multiple sensory modalities). Several hypotheses exist regarding the evolution and function of complex signaling including hypotheses relating to (a) the information content or message(s) conveyed, (b) the efficacy with which a signal(s) travels through the environment and is received and/or processed by a receiver, and (c) the potential for one signal to alter either the production, reception, or processing of a second signal. This project is aimed at understanding the evolution and function of complex signaling in the wolf spider genus Schizocosa. Within Schizocosa, multimodal courtship signaling (visual plus seismic) has evolved independently multiple times. This project examines the role of signal efficacy, signal content, and the potential interdependence of the two on complex signal function across 11 populations of Schizocosa encompassing 7 species and uses both field and laboratory based data collection and experimentation. Results from this study will not only provide foundational information regarding selection pressures influencing the evolution of complex signaling, but they will also likely provide insights into the details of modality-specific sensory perception and processing, neuronal interactions between modalities, and the influence of multimodal signals on signal detection/discrimination and learning and memory.

In addition to providing innumerable research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, this research will be incorporated into a youth science camp during the University of Nebraska's Big Red Week. Scientists involved in the project will help increase the public's scientific awareness by leading nighttime spider hunts with rural youth groups in the Midwest and with church youth groups and Girl Scout Troops across the south. This project will also contribute greatly to the invertebrate collection at the University of Nebraska State Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER grant focused on the evolution and function of complex courtship signaling in Schizocosa wolf spiders. Across the 23 described North American species (1), tremendous variation exists in the complexity of courtship displays, both within and between sensory modalities (vibratory and visual). Males of all Schizocosa produce a species-specific vibratory courtship song, with the number of combined elements variable across species. In addition to these vibratory songs, males of some species incorporate simultaneous visual displays involving ornamentation and dynamic movements (e.g. leg tapping, waving, arching). Intriguingly, the largest differences in multimodal courtship displays appear to be between sister-taxa (Figure 1). The ultimate goals of my research program are to (i) gain an understanding of the selection pressure(s) that influence the evolution of courtship displays, and (ii) explore the role of multimodal courtship divergence in speciation. The aims for this grant period were to determine the relative importance of vibratory and visual courtship signaling across multiple species of Schizocosa and to explore potential functions of multimodal signaling (2).

For each focal species, we conducted signal-ablation experiments in the laboratory in which we artificially removed the successful transmission of modality-specific signals independently (vibration and visual) by manipulating the signaling environment. Using an elegant 2 x 2 experimental design (visual present/vibration present; visual present/vibration absent; visual absent/vibration present; visual absent/vibration absent), we ran mate choice trials with single female-male pairs and recorded mating success. Across 9 focal Schizocosa species, we determined that the vibratory signal was crucial for mating success in 7 species, while the visual signal was only important for 2 species (3-7).These studies highlight the fundamental importance of vibratory signaling and results are consistent with the hypothesis that vibration-only courtship displays are ancestral in this genus.

Numerous studies associated with this funding resulted in the important discoveries that courtship signals across sensory modalities can interact and that female mate choice decisions can be quite complex, often relying on trait interactions (e.g.,  8, 9, 10). Females of S. uetzi, S. crassipes, and another close relative, Rabidosa rabida, respond to variation in visual courtship signaling (i.e. degree of ornamentation) only in the presence of a vibratory signal (3, 7, 11), suggesting that the vibratory signal may alter a female’s visual attention (for discussion see 3). In R. rabida, female mating decisions are dependent upon both female age and condition (12); and in S. floridana, females are choosy only in the dark – when only one signaling modality can be assessed (vibratory; 6). These studies highlight the importance of holistic approaches to multimodal signal function, demonstrating how experimental designs and analyses that allow for trait interactions and assessment of receiver variability are required for a complete picture of multimodal signal evolution and function.

Data collected from the multiple focal species during the course of this grant have enabled us to conduct the first phylogenetic analysis of complex signal evolution in Schizocosa wolf spiders.
